<ce:section-title id="st005">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">A novel fluorescent Tb-MOF with a new π-electron rich tetracarboxylic acid 5,5′-(9H-carbazole-3,6-diyl)diisophthalic acid has been synthesized under solvothermal condition. The Tb-MOF exhibits a 3D porous framework constructed via paddle-wheel [Tb<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>] subunit. The fine grinding particles of Tb-MOF dispersed in ethanol exhibits high efficiency detection for picric acid (PA).</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

A novel fluorescent Tb-MOF with a new π-electron rich tetracarboxylic acid 5,5'-(9H-carbazole-3,6-diyl)diisophthalic acid has been synthesized under solvothermal condition. The Tb-MOF exhibits a 3D porous framework constructed via paddle-wheel [Tb2(CO2)8] subunit. The fine grinding particles of Tb-MOF dispersed in ethanol exhibits high efficiency detection for picric acid (PA).

</ce:simple-para><ce:section-title id="st010">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">A lanthanide-organic framework constructed from a new π-electron rich ligand 5,5′-(9H-carbazole-3,6-diyl)diisophthalic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L) and Tb(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, namely, [(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][TbL] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), has been synthesized under solvothermal condition. X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits a 3D porous framework featuring a (4,8)-connected <ce:italic>sqc</ce:italic> net. The solid sample of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits strong green fluorescence in the visible region upon excitation at 354<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. The fine grinding particles of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> dispersed in ethanol shows good sensitivity for picric acid (PA), which can be reused at least five times for detecting PA. The good sensitivity and recyclability of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> make it a potential fluorescent sensor for explosives detection.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A lanthanide-organic framework constructed from a new π-electron rich ligand 5,5'-(9H-carbazole-3,6-diyl)diisophthalic acid (H4L) and Tb(NO3)3⋅6H2O, namely, [(CH3)2NH2][TbL] (1), has been synthesized under solvothermal condition. X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 1 exhibits a 3D porous framework featuring a (4,8)-connected sqc net. The solid sample of 1 exhibits strong green fluorescence in the visible region upon excitation at 354nm. The fine grinding particles of 1 dispersed in ethanol shows good sensitivity for picric acid (PA), which can be reused at least five times for detecting PA. The good sensitivity and recyclability of 1 make it a potential fluorescent sensor for explosives detection.

<ce:section-title id="st020">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">With the increasing use of nitroaromatic explosive materials in terrorism all over the world, rapid detection methods for tracing nitroaromatic explosive materials are in strong demand concerning security screening, homeland security, environmental monitoring and human health . Hence, various methods to detect nitroaromatic explosives have been developed, such as gas chromatography coupled with mass spectrometry , surface enhanced Raman spectroscopy , neutron activation analysis , ion mobility spectroscopy (IMS)  and electrochemical method . These instrumental techniques are expensive and may not always be easily accessible. Fluorescence quenching based sensing is a much simpler, sensitive and convenient technique . Electron donor conjugated polymers have proven to be excellent candidates for the detection of nitroaromatic explosives. The delocalized π electrons of such polymers can increase the electrostatic interaction between the polymers and electron-deficient nitroaromatic analytes .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

With the increasing use of nitroaromatic explosive materials in terrorism all over the world, rapid detection methods for tracing nitroaromatic explosive materials are in strong demand concerning security screening, homeland security, environmental monitoring and human health . Hence, various methods to detect nitroaromatic explosives have been developed, such as gas chromatography coupled with mass spectrometry , surface enhanced Raman spectroscopy , neutron activation analysis , ion mobility spectroscopy (IMS)  and electrochemical method . These instrumental techniques are expensive and may not always be easily accessible. Fluorescence quenching based sensing is a much simpler, sensitive and convenient technique . Electron donor conjugated polymers have proven to be excellent candidates for the detection of nitroaromatic explosives. The delocalized π electrons of such polymers can increase the electrostatic interaction between the polymers and electron-deficient nitroaromatic analytes .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Recently, fluorescent MOFs have drawn considerable attention for nitroaromatic explosive sensing . Due to the controllable size and porosity, structural stability and high surface area, fluorescent MOFs exhibit advantages over other fluorescent materials. The fluorescent MOFs can allow more analytes to come into contact with the MOF surface, which may improve the sensitivity. It is well-known that the fluorescent behavior of a MOF highly depends on the organic linker and metal ion. Therefore, enhanced performance can be accomplished by elaborate selection of the organic linker and metal ions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Recently, fluorescent MOFs have drawn considerable attention for nitroaromatic explosive sensing . Due to the controllable size and porosity, structural stability and high surface area, fluorescent MOFs exhibit advantages over other fluorescent materials. The fluorescent MOFs can allow more analytes to come into contact with the MOF surface, which may improve the sensitivity. It is well-known that the fluorescent behavior of a MOF highly depends on the organic linker and metal ion. Therefore, enhanced performance can be accomplished by elaborate selection of the organic linker and metal ions.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Here, we designed and synthesized a π-electron rich polycarboxylates ligand 5,5′-(9H-carbazole-3,6-diyl)diisophthalic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L). Considering that most of the Ln-MOFs exhibit excellent luminescence properties, lanthanide Tb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> was choosed as the metal connector to synthesize fluorescent MOFs. We employed this ligand to react with lanthanide Tb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> to construct a new luminescent 3D Tb-MOF [(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][TbL] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>). Because the H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L ligand can effectively sensitize the emission of Tb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>, the solid sample of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> emits high bright green light upon excitation at 354<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. The fine grinding particles of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> dispersed in ethanol exhibit selective sensing of nitroaromatic explosives, indicating the Tb-MOF can be a good candidate for fluorescent sensor.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Here, we designed and synthesized a π-electron rich polycarboxylates ligand 5,5'-(9H-carbazole-3,6-diyl)diisophthalic acid (H4L). Considering that most of the Ln-MOFs exhibit excellent luminescence properties, lanthanide Tb3+ was choosed as the metal connector to synthesize fluorescent MOFs. We employed this ligand to react with lanthanide Tb3+ to construct a new luminescent 3D Tb-MOF [(CH3)2NH2][TbL] (1). Because the H4L ligand can effectively sensitize the emission of Tb3+, the solid sample of 1 emits high bright green light upon excitation at 354nm. The fine grinding particles of 1 dispersed in ethanol exhibit selective sensing of nitroaromatic explosives, indicating the Tb-MOF can be a good candidate for fluorescent sensor.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental

General information and materials

Except for the H4L ligand, all other chemicals were commercially available and used without further purification. IR data were recorded on a BRUKER TENSOR II spectrophotometer with KBr pellets in the region of 400-4000cm-1. Elemental analyses (C, H and N) were carried out on a Flash EA 1112 elemental analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were finished with a Bruker AXS D8 Advance using Cu Kα radiation. Thermal analyses were performed on a Netzsch STA 449C thermal analyzer at a heating rate of 10°Cmin-1 in air. 1H NMR was determined on Bruker DPX 600 nuclear magnetic resonance spectrometer. The luminescence spectra for the powdered solid samples were measured at room temperature on a Hitachi F-7000 Fluorescence Spectrophotometer. The excitation slit and the emission slit were 5nm (PMT Voltage=400V). The scan speed is 1200nm/min. The fluorescent sensing properties of 1 were examined under the same conditions.

Synthesis

Synthesis of 5,5'-(9H-carbazole-3,6-diyl)diisophthalicacid (H4L) ()

 3,6-Dibromo-9H-carbazole was prepared according to the literature .

Under a nitrogen atmosphere, to a solution of 3,6-dibromo-9H-carbazole (325mg, 1mmol) in DMF solvent (30mL) were added dimethyl 5-(4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-1,3,2-dioxaborolan-2-yl)isophthalate (640mg, 2mmol), Pd(PPh3)4 (93mg, 0.05mmol), K2CO3 (324mg, 3mmol). After the mixture was stirred at 100°C for 18h, then filtered and concentrated. The crude product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel with dichloromethane/methanol (100:5, V:V) to give pure tetramethyl 5,5'-(9H-carbazole-3,6-diyl)diisophthalate as a gray solid. Yelid: 330mg, 60%. 1H NMR (600MHz, DMSO-d 6): δ 11.557 (s, 1H), 8.858 (s, 2H), 8.559 (s, 4H), 8.439 (s, 2H), 7.832 (d, 2H), 7.645 (d, 2H), 4.519(s, 12H). MS m/z 550.2 (M+H+).

Synthesis of [(CH3)2NH2][TbL] (1)

A mixture of Tb(NO3)3⋅6H2O (45.3mg, 0.1mmol), H4L (24.7mg, 0.05mmol) and NaOH (8.0mg, 0.2mmol) in 5mL of the component solvent (DMF:CH3CN:H2O=3:1:1) was sealed in a 25mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated to 160°C for 72h. After the mixture was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5°Ch-1, colorless crystals of 1 were obtained with a yield of 65% (based on Tb). Anal. Calc. for C18H17N2O4Tb (%): C, 51.74; H, 3.04; N, 4.02. Found: C, 51.80; H, 3.08; N, 4.03%. IR (cm-1, KBr): 3423s, 1771w, 1734w, 1715w, 1698w, 1650w, 1620w, 1557w, 1539w, 1522w, 1508w, 1456w, 1287w, 849m, 820w, 785m, 718m, 595m.

elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure determination

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurement was collected on a Bruker SMART APEX-II CCD diffractometer for 1 at temperature of 23±1°C using graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.71073Å). Absorption corrections were applied by using multi-scan program. The data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined with a full-matrix least-squares technique based on F 2 with the shelxl-97 crystallographic software package . The hydrogen atoms were assigned with common isotropic displacement factors and included in the final refinement by using geometrical restrains. The molecular formula of 1 was calculated and confirmed by the elemental analysis data and thermogravimetric analysis, because the SQUEEZE function in platon was applied . Crystallographic crystal data and structure processing parameters for complex 1 are summarized in detail in  . Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in .

<ce:section-title id="st055">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st060">Crystal structure description</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Single-crystal X-ray analysis indicates that complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the tetragonal crystal system with space group of <ce:italic>I-4</ce:italic>2<ce:italic>d</ce:italic>. The asymmetrical unit of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> contains half a Tb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion, half a L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand and the negative charge of the framework is balanced by half a (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> cation, which was generated from the decomposed DMF. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>a, the central Tb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion possesses an eight-coordinated square antiprism coordination mode, being linked to eight carboxylate oxygen atoms from six different L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligands. The Tb–O bond lengths vary from 2.260(5) to 2.501(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which are similar to those reported in other Tb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> compounds . Two symmetry related Tb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions are bridged by carboxylate groups to form a noteworthy paddle-wheel [Tb<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>] subunit with a Tb⋯Tb distance of 4.2938(17)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Each L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> anion coordinates to 8 Tb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions, with carboxylate groups adopting two kinds of coordination modes: μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> and μ<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>-η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> mode. Finally, each binuclear [Tb<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>] subunit are linked by L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> anions to generate a fascinating 3D porous framework (b). The solvent-accessible volume in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is 2206.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, equal to 36.6% of the volume of the unit cell calculated by the <ce:small-caps>platon</ce:small-caps> program. Topological analysis was carried out to get insight into the structure . As shown in c, the L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> anions and the [Tb<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>] subunits can be defined as 4- and 8-connected nodes, respectively. Therefore, complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be simplified as a (4,8)-connected <ce:italic>sqc</ce:italic> network with Schläfli symbol of (4<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>)(4<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6<ce:sup loc="post">16</ce:sup>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Crystal structure description

Single-crystal X-ray analysis indicates that complex 1 crystallizes in the tetragonal crystal system with space group of I-42d. The asymmetrical unit of 1 contains half a Tb3+ ion, half a L4- ligand and the negative charge of the framework is balanced by half a (CH3)2NH2 + cation, which was generated from the decomposed DMF. As shown in  a, the central Tb3+ ion possesses an eight-coordinated square antiprism coordination mode, being linked to eight carboxylate oxygen atoms from six different L4- ligands. The Tb-O bond lengths vary from 2.260(5) to 2.501(5)Å, which are similar to those reported in other Tb3+ compounds . Two symmetry related Tb3+ ions are bridged by carboxylate groups to form a noteworthy paddle-wheel [Tb2(CO2)8] subunit with a Tb⋯Tb distance of 4.2938(17)Å. Each L4- anion coordinates to 8 Tb3+ ions, with carboxylate groups adopting two kinds of coordination modes: μ2-η1:η1 and μ1-η1:η1 mode. Finally, each binuclear [Tb2(CO2)8] subunit are linked by L4- anions to generate a fascinating 3D porous framework (b). The solvent-accessible volume in 1 is 2206.6Å3, equal to 36.6% of the volume of the unit cell calculated by the platon program. Topological analysis was carried out to get insight into the structure . As shown in c, the L4- anions and the [Tb2(CO2)8] subunits can be defined as 4- and 8-connected nodes, respectively. Therefore, complex 1 can be simplified as a (4,8)-connected sqc network with Schläfli symbol of (43 ⋅63)(412 ⋅616).

The peak positions of experimental PXRD patterns are in line with the simulated ones, showing the pure phase of the complex. As shown in , the TGA of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows an initial gradual weight loss of 6.12% between 85<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and 242<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, corresponding to the release of (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> (Calc.: 6.62%). The compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> begins to decompose upon further heating and underwent a rapid weight loss of 64.58% from 242<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C to 563<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, corresponding to the destruction of the H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L ligands.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
PXRD patterns and thermogravimetric analysis

The PXRD patterns of complex 1 are shown in . The peak positions of experimental PXRD patterns are in line with the simulated ones, showing the pure phase of the complex. As shown in , the TGA of 1 shows an initial gradual weight loss of 6.12% between 85°C and 242°C, corresponding to the release of (CH3)2NH2 + (Calc.: 6.62%). The compound 1 begins to decompose upon further heating and underwent a rapid weight loss of 64.58% from 242°C to 563°C, corresponding to the destruction of the H4L ligands.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st070">Fluorescence behaviors and sensing properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The lanthanide coordination polymers have displayed excellent fluorescence properties in the respect of their high color purity . So we investigated the ligand-assisted fluorescence properties of powder samples of the lanthanide complex at room temperature (). When excited at 354<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits the characteristic emissions of Tb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions in the visible region. The emission peaks at 490, 545, 585 and 621<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm can be attributed to the transitions of <ce:sup loc="pre">5</ce:sup>D<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>–<ce:sup loc="pre">7</ce:sup>F<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">J</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:italic>J</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6, 5, 4, 3) from Tb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions, respectively. Upon excitation at 243<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, the free H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L ligand exhibits a luminescent emission band at 388<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, which is attributed to the π–π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup> transition. The luminescent investigation on the complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> suggests that H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L ligand may sensitize the luminescence of Tb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions. The strongest emission in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> appears at 545<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm which can be easily observed as bright green light by the naked eye. The remarkable fluorescence offers the possibility of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> being a fluorescence sensor.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence behaviors and sensing properties

The lanthanide coordination polymers have displayed excellent fluorescence properties in the respect of their high color purity . So we investigated the ligand-assisted fluorescence properties of powder samples of the lanthanide complex at room temperature (). When excited at 354nm, complex 1 exhibits the characteristic emissions of Tb3+ ions in the visible region. The emission peaks at 490, 545, 585 and 621nm can be attributed to the transitions of 5D4-7F J  (J =6, 5, 4, 3) from Tb3+ ions, respectively. Upon excitation at 243nm, the free H4L ligand exhibits a luminescent emission band at 388nm, which is attributed to the π-π∗ transition. The luminescent investigation on the complex 1 suggests that H4L ligand may sensitize the luminescence of Tb3+ ions. The strongest emission in 1 appears at 545nm which can be easily observed as bright green light by the naked eye. The remarkable fluorescence offers the possibility of 1 being a fluorescence sensor.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0065" view="all">To explore the potential photoluminescence sensing properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the fine grinding sample of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg) was dispersed in 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of various solvents (EtOH, MeCN, DMF, CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, THF, acetone, H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, toluene (TO), benzene (BZ), nitrobenzene(NB)) sonicated for 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min and the emission was observed. The fluorescence intensities are mainly dependent on the solvent molecules, which present different fluorescence quenching degree (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>). Among the chosen solvents, the severe quenching of fluorescence intensity was observed in NB, indicating that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has a selective response to NB. The mechanism of fluorescence quenching might be attributed to the photoinduced electron transfer from an excited MOF to the highly electron deficient NB adsorbed on the surface of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
. The fluorescence quenching of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is similar to that reported for many other fluorescent MOFs in order to account for their highly selective sensing behavior towards NB .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: To explore the potential photoluminescence sensing properties of 1, the fine grinding sample of 1 (3mg) was dispersed in 3mL of various solvents (EtOH, MeCN, DMF, CH2Cl2, THF, acetone, H2O, toluene (TO), benzene (BZ), nitrobenzene(NB)) sonicated for 30min and the emission was observed. The fluorescence intensities are mainly dependent on the solvent molecules, which present different fluorescence quenching degree ( ). Among the chosen solvents, the severe quenching of fluorescence intensity was observed in NB, indicating that 1 has a selective response to NB. The mechanism of fluorescence quenching might be attributed to the photoinduced electron transfer from an excited MOF to the highly electron deficient NB adsorbed on the surface of 1 . The fluorescence quenching of 1 is similar to that reported for many other fluorescent MOFs in order to account for their highly selective sensing behavior towards NB .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0070" view="all">The sensing properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> for NB prompted us to investigate its application in detecting different electron-withdrawing nitroaromatics. The nitroaromatics such as 4-nitrotoulene (4-NT), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), 4-ni-tro-chlorobenzene (4-NC), 2,4-dinitro-chlorobenzene (2,4-DNC), picric acid (PA) were added to a suspension of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg) in ethanol (3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL). As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>, upon the addition of the same amount of nitroaromatics ([nitroaromatics]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm), different degrees of fluorescence quenching of the suspension were tested. The descending order of quenching efficiency was PA<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4-NC<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2,4-DNC<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2,4-DNT<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4-NT<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>NB. About quenching efficiency (QE<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>(1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>F</ce:italic>/<ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>100% (<ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf> and <ce:italic>F</ce:italic> are the fluorescent intensities before and after the addition of nitroaromatics, respectively.)) of 76.9% for PA is observed, which is significantly more than that of 4-NC (29.2%), indicating that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows a high selectivity for PA.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The sensing properties of 1 for NB prompted us to investigate its application in detecting different electron-withdrawing nitroaromatics. The nitroaromatics such as 4-nitrotoulene (4-NT), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), 4-ni-tro-chlorobenzene (4-NC), 2,4-dinitro-chlorobenzene (2,4-DNC), picric acid (PA) were added to a suspension of 1 (3mg) in ethanol (3mL). As shown in  , upon the addition of the same amount of nitroaromatics ([nitroaromatics]=10ppm), different degrees of fluorescence quenching of the suspension were tested. The descending order of quenching efficiency was PA>4-NC>2,4-DNC>2,4-DNT>4-NT>NB. About quenching efficiency (QE=(1- F/F 0)×100% (F 0 and F are the fluorescent intensities before and after the addition of nitroaromatics, respectively.)) of 76.9% for PA is observed, which is significantly more than that of 4-NC (29.2%), indicating that 1 shows a high selectivity for PA.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0075" view="all">To further study the sensing capacity of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> for PA, the emission spectra are monitored by gradually increasing PA contents of a suspension of 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> dispersed in 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL ethanol. The fluorescent intensity obviously decreased with the increasing PA concentration (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>). When the concentration of PA reached 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm, the quenching efficiency was 94.2% for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, which is higher than or comparable to other MOF sensors, polymeric nanocomposites  and conjugated polymer sensors for PA. For example, the micrometer-sized MOF [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(TPT)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(DMF)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf> show an 82.5% quenching efficiency for PA . The quenching efficiency of the reported carbon and silver nanocomposites for PA is 99% . The fluorescence intensity of conjugated polymer flim only decreased with 77-fold fluorescence quenching . After immersing into the PA solution (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mM in ethanol) for 12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are collected by filtration, washed with EtOH and air-dried. Then the PXRD measurement was performed. The PXRD result indicates that the crystallinity of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was still remained after the experiment ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: To further study the sensing capacity of 1 for PA, the emission spectra are monitored by gradually increasing PA contents of a suspension of 3mg of 1 dispersed in 3mL ethanol. The fluorescent intensity obviously decreased with the increasing PA concentration ( ). When the concentration of PA reached 30ppm, the quenching efficiency was 94.2% for 1, which is higher than or comparable to other MOF sensors, polymeric nanocomposites  and conjugated polymer sensors for PA. For example, the micrometer-sized MOF [Cd3(TPT)2(DMF)2]⋅(H2O)0.5 show an 82.5% quenching efficiency for PA . The quenching efficiency of the reported carbon and silver nanocomposites for PA is 99% . The fluorescence intensity of conjugated polymer flim only decreased with 77-fold fluorescence quenching . After immersing into the PA solution (1mM in ethanol) for 12h, crystals of 1 are collected by filtration, washed with EtOH and air-dried. Then the PXRD measurement was performed. The PXRD result indicates that the crystallinity of 1 was still remained after the experiment ().

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0080" view="all">The reusability of a sensor is a critical problem for the long-term practical applications. So, the recyclability experiments of the particles of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> for sensing PA were carried out up to five cycles. The particles of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> could be recovered by centrifugation of the dispersed solution and washing three times with ethanol. The luminescent intensity and quenching ability of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are essentially retained in 1–5 cycles (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>). The results demonstrated that the complex has high reproducibility for explosive detection.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The reusability of a sensor is a critical problem for the long-term practical applications. So, the recyclability experiments of the particles of 1 for sensing PA were carried out up to five cycles. The particles of 1 could be recovered by centrifugation of the dispersed solution and washing three times with ethanol. The luminescent intensity and quenching ability of 1 are essentially retained in 1-5 cycles ( ). The results demonstrated that the complex has high reproducibility for explosive detection.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st075">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">In conclusion, we have successfully synthesized a novel fluorescent Tb-MOF [(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][TbL] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) with a new π-electron rich tetracarboxylic acid H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L. The complex exhibits a 3D porous framework constructed via paddle-wheel [Tb<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>] subunit. The solid-state fluorescent measurements indicated that the ligand H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L can sensitize the fluorescence intensities of Tb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions, resulting in the strong fluorescence emission of Tb-MOF. The fine grinding particles of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> dispersed in ethanol exhibits a high quenching efficiency for PA. The application of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> may enable further development of new chemosensors for explosives.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, we have successfully synthesized a novel fluorescent Tb-MOF [(CH3)2NH2][TbL] (1) with a new π-electron rich tetracarboxylic acid H4L. The complex exhibits a 3D porous framework constructed via paddle-wheel [Tb2(CO2)8] subunit. The solid-state fluorescent measurements indicated that the ligand H4L can sensitize the fluorescence intensities of Tb3+ ions, resulting in the strong fluorescence emission of Tb-MOF. The fine grinding particles of 1 dispersed in ethanol exhibits a high quenching efficiency for PA. The application of 1 may enable further development of new chemosensors for explosives.

Synthesis

Synthesis of 5,5'-(9H-carbazole-3,6-diyl)diisophthalicacid (H4L) ()

 3,6-Dibromo-9H-carbazole was prepared according to the literature .

Under a nitrogen atmosphere, to a solution of 3,6-dibromo-9H-carbazole (325mg, 1mmol) in DMF solvent (30mL) were added dimethyl 5-(4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-1,3,2-dioxaborolan-2-yl)isophthalate (640mg, 2mmol), Pd(PPh3)4 (93mg, 0.05mmol), K2CO3 (324mg, 3mmol). After the mixture was stirred at 100°C for 18h, then filtered and concentrated. The crude product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel with dichloromethane/methanol (100:5, V:V) to give pure tetramethyl 5,5'-(9H-carbazole-3,6-diyl)diisophthalate as a gray solid. Yelid: 330mg, 60%. 1H NMR (600MHz, DMSO-d 6): δ 11.557 (s, 1H), 8.858 (s, 2H), 8.559 (s, 4H), 8.439 (s, 2H), 7.832 (d, 2H), 7.645 (d, 2H), 4.519(s, 12H). MS m/z 550.2 (M+H+).

Tetramethyl 5,5'-(9H-carbazole-3,6-diyl)diisophthalate (551 mmg,1mmol) was dissolved in 20mL of mixed solvent of THF and MeOH (v/v=1:1). Then 10mL of 20% NaOH aqueous solution was added to the above solution. The mixture was constantly stirred at 80°C for 24h. After that, the organic phase was removed under reduced pressure. The remaining aqueous phase was acidified by dilute hydrochloric acid to obtain a gray precipitate, which was filtered and washed with water. Yield: 410mg, 83%. 1H NMR (600MHz, DMSO-d 6): δ 13.394 (s, 4H), 11.557 (s, 1H), 8.858 (s, 2H), 8.559 (s, 4H), 8.439 (s, 2H), 7.832 (d, 2H), 7.645 (d, 2H). MS m/z 494.2 (M+H+).

Synthesis of [(CH3)2NH2][TbL] (1)

A mixture of Tb(NO3)3⋅6H2O (45.3mg, 0.1mmol), H4L (24.7mg, 0.05mmol) and NaOH (8.0mg, 0.2mmol) in 5mL of the component solvent (DMF:CH3CN:H2O=3:1:1) was sealed in a 25mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated to 160°C for 72h. After the mixture was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5°Ch-1, colorless crystals of 1 were obtained with a yield of 65% (based on Tb). Anal. Calc. for C18H17N2O4Tb (%): C, 51.74; H, 3.04; N, 4.02. Found: C, 51.80; H, 3.08; N, 4.03%. IR (cm-1, KBr): 3423s, 1771w, 1734w, 1715w, 1698w, 1650w, 1620w, 1557w, 1539w, 1522w, 1508w, 1456w, 1287w, 849m, 820w, 785m, 718m, 595m.

<ce:link id="lk00035" locator="fx1" xlink:href="pii:S0277538716306817/fx1" xlink:role="http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/ElsevierContentTypes/23.4"></ce:link>

</ce:simple-para><ce:section-title id="st010">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">A lanthanide-organic framework constructed from a new π-electron rich ligand 5,5′-(9H-carbazole-3,6-diyl)diisophthalic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L) and Tb(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, namely, [(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][TbL] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), has been synthesized under solvothermal condition. X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits a 3D porous framework featuring a (4,8)-connected <ce:italic>sqc</ce:italic> net. The solid sample of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits strong green fluorescence in the visible region upon excitation at 354<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. The fine grinding particles of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> dispersed in ethanol shows good sensitivity for picric acid (PA), which can be reused at least five times for detecting PA. The good sensitivity and recyclability of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> make it a potential fluorescent sensor for explosives detection.</ce:simple-para><ce:section-title id="st055">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st060">Crystal structure description</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Single-crystal X-ray analysis indicates that complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the tetragonal crystal system with space group of <ce:italic>I-4</ce:italic>2<ce:italic>d</ce:italic>. The asymmetrical unit of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> contains half a Tb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion, half a L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand and the negative charge of the framework is balanced by half a (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> cation, which was generated from the decomposed DMF. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>a, the central Tb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion possesses an eight-coordinated square antiprism coordination mode, being linked to eight carboxylate oxygen atoms from six different L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligands. The Tb–O bond lengths vary from 2.260(5) to 2.501(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which are similar to those reported in other Tb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> compounds . Two symmetry related Tb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions are bridged by carboxylate groups to form a noteworthy paddle-wheel [Tb<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>] subunit with a Tb⋯Tb distance of 4.2938(17)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Each L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> anion coordinates to 8 Tb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions, with carboxylate groups adopting two kinds of coordination modes: μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> and μ<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>-η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> mode. Finally, each binuclear [Tb<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>] subunit are linked by L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> anions to generate a fascinating 3D porous framework (b). The solvent-accessible volume in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is 2206.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, equal to 36.6% of the volume of the unit cell calculated by the <ce:small-caps>platon</ce:small-caps> program. Topological analysis was carried out to get insight into the structure . As shown in c, the L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> anions and the [Tb<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>] subunits can be defined as 4- and 8-connected nodes, respectively. Therefore, complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be simplified as a (4,8)-connected <ce:italic>sqc</ce:italic> network with Schläfli symbol of (4<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>)(4<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6<ce:sup loc="post">16</ce:sup>).</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st065">PXRD patterns and thermogravimetric analysis</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">The PXRD patterns of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are shown in . The peak positions of experimental PXRD patterns are in line with the simulated ones, showing the pure phase of the complex. As shown in , the TGA of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows an initial gradual weight loss of 6.12% between 85<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and 242<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, corresponding to the release of (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> (Calc.: 6.62%). cln_elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A lanthanide-organic framework constructed from a new π-electron rich ligand 5,5'-(9H-carbazole-3,6-diyl)diisophthalic acid (H4L) and Tb(NO3)3⋅6H2O, namely, [(CH3)2NH2][TbL] (1), has been synthesized under solvothermal condition. X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 1 exhibits a 3D porous framework featuring a (4,8)-connected sqc net. The solid sample of 1 exhibits strong green fluorescence in the visible region upon excitation at 354nm. The fine grinding particles of 1 dispersed in ethanol shows good sensitivity for picric acid (PA), which can be reused at least five times for detecting PA. The good sensitivity and recyclability of 1 make it a potential fluorescent sensor for explosives detection.

Results and discussion

Crystal structure description

Single-crystal X-ray analysis indicates that complex 1 crystallizes in the tetragonal crystal system with space group of I-42d. The asymmetrical unit of 1 contains half a Tb3+ ion, half a L4- ligand and the negative charge of the framework is balanced by half a (CH3)2NH2 + cation, which was generated from the decomposed DMF. As shown in  a, the central Tb3+ ion possesses an eight-coordinated square antiprism coordination mode, being linked to eight carboxylate oxygen atoms from six different L4- ligands. The Tb-O bond lengths vary from 2.260(5) to 2.501(5)Å, which are similar to those reported in other Tb3+ compounds . Two symmetry related Tb3+ ions are bridged by carboxylate groups to form a noteworthy paddle-wheel [Tb2(CO2)8] subunit with a Tb⋯Tb distance of 4.2938(17)Å. Each L4- anion coordinates to 8 Tb3+ ions, with carboxylate groups adopting two kinds of coordination modes: μ2-η1:η1 and μ1-η1:η1 mode. Finally, each binuclear [Tb2(CO2)8] subunit are linked by L4- anions to generate a fascinating 3D porous framework (b). The solvent-accessible volume in 1 is 2206.6Å3, equal to 36.6% of the volume of the unit cell calculated by the platon program. Topological analysis was carried out to get insight into the structure . As shown in c, the L4- anions and the [Tb2(CO2)8] subunits can be defined as 4- and 8-connected nodes, respectively. Therefore, complex 1 can be simplified as a (4,8)-connected sqc network with Schläfli symbol of (43 ⋅63)(412 ⋅616).

PXRD patterns and thermogravimetric analysis

The PXRD patterns of complex 1 are shown in . The peak positions of experimental PXRD patterns are in line with the simulated ones, showing the pure phase of the complex. As shown in , the TGA of 1 shows an initial gradual weight loss of 6.12% between 85°C and 242°C, corresponding to the release of (CH3)2NH2 + (Calc.: 6.62%). The compound 1 begins to decompose upon further heating and underwent a rapid weight loss of 64.58% from 242°C to 563°C, corresponding to the destruction of the H4L ligands.

Fluorescence behaviors and sensing properties

The lanthanide coordination polymers have displayed excellent fluorescence properties in the respect of their high color purity . So we investigated the ligand-assisted fluorescence properties of powder samples of the lanthanide complex at room temperature (). When excited at 354nm, complex 1 exhibits the characteristic emissions of Tb3+ ions in the visible region. The emission peaks at 490, 545, 585 and 621nm can be attributed to the transitions of 5D4-7F J  (J =6, 5, 4, 3) from Tb3+ ions, respectively. Upon excitation at 243nm, the free H4L ligand exhibits a luminescent emission band at 388nm, which is attributed to the π-π∗ transition. The luminescent investigation on the complex 1 suggests that H4L ligand may sensitize the luminescence of Tb3+ ions. The strongest emission in 1 appears at 545nm which can be easily observed as bright green light by the naked eye. The remarkable fluorescence offers the possibility of 1 being a fluorescence sensor.

The sensing properties of 1 for NB prompted us to investigate its application in detecting different electron-withdrawing nitroaromatics. The nitroaromatics such as 4-nitrotoulene (4-NT), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), 4-ni-tro-chlorobenzene (4-NC), 2,4-dinitro-chlorobenzene (2,4-DNC), picric acid (PA) were added to a suspension of 1 (3mg) in ethanol (3mL). As shown in  , upon the addition of the same amount of nitroaromatics ([nitroaromatics]=10ppm), different degrees of fluorescence quenching of the suspension were tested. The descending order of quenching efficiency was PA>4-NC>2,4-DNC>2,4-DNT>4-NT>NB. About quenching efficiency (QE=(1- F/F 0)×100% (F 0 and F are the fluorescent intensities before and after the addition of nitroaromatics, respectively.)) of 76.9% for PA is observed, which is significantly more than that of 4-NC (29.2%), indicating that 1 shows a high selectivity for PA.

To further study the sensing capacity of 1 for PA, the emission spectra are monitored by gradually increasing PA contents of a suspension of 3mg of 1 dispersed in 3mL ethanol. The fluorescent intensity obviously decreased with the increasing PA concentration ( ). When the concentration of PA reached 30ppm, the quenching efficiency was 94.2% for 1, which is higher than or comparable to other MOF sensors, polymeric nanocomposites  and conjugated polymer sensors for PA. For example, the micrometer-sized MOF [Cd3(TPT)2(DMF)2]⋅(H2O)0.5 show an 82.5% quenching efficiency for PA . The quenching efficiency of the reported carbon and silver nanocomposites for PA is 99% . The fluorescence intensity of conjugated polymer flim only decreased with 77-fold fluorescence quenching . After immersing into the PA solution (1mM in ethanol) for 12h, crystals of 1 are collected by filtration, washed with EtOH and air-dried. Then the PXRD measurement was performed. The PXRD result indicates that the crystallinity of 1 was still remained after the experiment ().
